Saying that GitHub needs to be decentralized is like saying that Coinbase needs to be decentralized... oh wait, that's *Bitcoin*. Git is already a distributed system.
Hosting, community features, nice UI. There are several self-hosted options (GitLab CE, Gogs, Gitea) which deliver essentially the same thing, GitHub is just easy.
It's funny how most efforts to decentralize somehow works their way back to being primarily centralized.

Before you jump to "it needs a blockchain", realize that anyone can host a Git repo without GitHub. You can then self-host something like https://gogs.io/ , https://gitea.io/en-US/  or https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce … to put a nice UI on top of it. All free and distributed.
Anyone can self-host a Git repo, then utilize an open-source UI such as GitLab if they want a convenient tool for issue reporting, etc.

It's Git hosting with a nice UI. Just like Coinbase is essentially Bitcoin wallet hosting with a nice UI. Both compromise decentralization for convenience - that doesn't mean you can't self-host. https://gitlab.com/  + https://bitbucket.org/  are also two popular alternatives

To anyone suggesting the potential Microsoft acquisition of GitHub means someone should "decentralized GitHub" or do "GitHub on the blockchain" - stop. Git is already a distributed system. GitHub is like the Coinbase of Git.
